data.title: Merge pull request #1 from godotengine/master
data.body: Sync with origin

data.title: Added lambda expressions and function object in GDScript.
data.body:
```
func _ready():

  # Easier connection
  self.connect("renamed", on_renamed)

  var hello = "hello"
  # lambda expressions
  var lambda_func = func():
      print(hello)

  # or 
  func lambda_func2():
      print(hello)

  # lambda_func is a function object
  lambda_func.apply()
  lambda_func2.apply()

  # A native function object
  var native_func = self.set_name
  native_func.apply("new_name")


func on_renamed():
  print(get_name())
```

data.title: Fix 3D editor align with current view
data.body:
In the 3D editor, when you try undo the "Align with view" option the position is not restored properly when you move, rotate or scale the node before performing the operation.

This fixes it by using the current camera transform and the node scale.

data.title: Module through export
data.body: Why do we have to recompile godot to have a module work? How about if instead of having to put the module in the modules folder and compile we can add the files in export when we want to release a game and have the module files added into the project.

data.title: Added project icon to some demos
data.body: Average size is 2~3 kB. 44,4 kB total.

data.title: Visual studio 2015 compilation
data.body:
With these changes I'm able to build godot successfully like this:

c:\python27\scripts\scons.bat vsproj=yes platform=windows -j8

For parallel builds, you need the [pywin32 extensions](http://sourceforge.net/projects/pywin32/). This reduces build time by a factor of 3 on my machine, which is a godsend! (3 instead of 9 minutes for a full rebuild). This resulted in an error before.

Everything works fine. A single *.pdb gets generated. release_debug builds with tools included are running fine. The executable has a size of 15.2 MB, which is quite smaller than the older builds. This is because there was a linker error which forced me to link to the c runtime dynamically. But this should be preferred anyway.

For reference: I'm Using Visual Studio 2015 Enterprise on Windows 10.

I remember, that there was a problem when Visual Studio 2013 and 2015 were installed on the same machine. Could be an error with scons. But I got a new notebook and just got 2015 installed. So keep that in mind.

data.title: Fix bug in Body(2D)SW::add_area
data.body:
Since my patch ( #1691 ) to implement AREA_COMBINE mode a bug was introduced in BodySW and Body2DSW add_area function.

The data structure containing the areas the body was in used to be a SET but was converted to an ARRAY to implement priority.

The rest of the engine though did not check if the body was already inside an area when calling body->add_area. This basically causes the _update_shape signal to add the same area multiple times to the same body object. A very quick test for this is to change the shape of an area in combine mode after _ready (even setting it as the same value it used to be).

If you want a very simple demo project to test both the bug and the patch have a look at:
https://github.com/Faless/add_area_bug

data.title: Set World2D default angular damp per global `physics_2d/default_angular_damp`
data.body:
Currently, the linear and angular damp of World2D are both set by `physics_2d/default_density`, resulting in the former overriding the latter's value.

This change adds `physics_2d/default_angular_damp` to set `AREA_PARAM_ANGULAR_DAMP`.

data.title: [New Scene system] Inherited scenes won't open in editor.
data.body:
In current build bd736e5af2ec5113c23fef58523f57a0b2e11fb2 it's impossible to open any scene that is created with "new inherited Scene" option. Bug is with us for at least couple days since I also tested it on d123c89c5802777e02402108d9271ed2f29368fe. 
Because of this bug it's impossible to use inherited scene feature (don't know any workaround).

_Further notes:_
**I have found commit that introduced this issue:** Issue was introduced in 884d5a0f41032a9c5c793577b82998998b3f87a0 commit. In fba1842b111420d75cfabc9dc4f240965cb085fe it's working fine.
It seems the bug is during writing/saving the scenes since I'm able to open scenes saved with little older Godot versions.

_Steps to reproduce:_
1. Create new scene, name it "BaseScene.xscn", put one node inside
2. Create inherited scene with base as "BaseScene.xscn", add one node.
3. Save it as "InheritedScene.xscn"
4. Close tabs and try to reopen "InheritedScene.xscn"

_TestCase project:_
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/168251/godot/some/issues/InheritanceSceneError.7z
_Quick prof video:_
https://youtu.be/xziKXmWDFZ4

Edit:
Here is godot editor console log when trying to open inherited scene:

```
ERROR: set_current_tab: Index p_current out of size (get_tab_count()).
   At: scene/gui/tabs.cpp:500.
TextureButton: 16,-4
Label: 128,63
HBoxContainer: 59,25
ERROR: remove_scene: Index p_idx out of size (edited_scene.size()).
   At: tools/editor/editor_data.cpp:475.
```

Looks like it might be related to: https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/2611

data.title: Alt codes aren’t picked up by text
data.body:
When trying to insert a character with an alt code in Godot, in any text field, it will not be picked up.

For this purpose, I tried to enter the curly apostrophe: ’ (Alt + 0146)

Example 1:
1. Open a new scene
2. Add a Label node
3. When writing text in the text field, enter Alt + 0146

Example 2:
1. Open a new scene
2. Add a TextEdit field
3. Save scene
4. Play scene
5. In the text field, try to enter Alt + 0146

Neither of these approaches will work.

data.title: Godot crashes when justifying RichTextLabel of default size
data.body:
Godot crashes when aligning text justified (or how Godot calls it, “fill”) in a RichTextLabel ~~set with a custom font~~.
1. Open a new scene
2. Add a RichTextLabel node
3. ~~Import a font (I used “Garogier”, but any should work)~~
4. Enable BBcode
5. Enter this in text:
   “[fill]Last thing I remember was we were playing hide and seek. Guess they either forgot about me or gave up, huh...[/fill]”
6. ~~Set the “Normal” font to the one imported previously~~

**Bugsquad edit:** removed unneeded steps to reproduce.

data.title: object.is_connected(Signal_ID) throws to error console that there is no such signal
data.body:
When signal is not connected then checking with is_connected() throws an error to error console that says "Nonexistent Signal: [Signal_Name]".  If the signal is already connected then it's fine.
Tested on 2.0 alpha commit: d123c89c5802777e02402108d9271ed2f29368fe
The program don't crash, just an error in debug console. The signal was defined with "signal" keyword. 

Sample project:
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/168251/godot/some/issues/NewSignalsEmptyError.7z

Fast video:
https://youtu.be/Qv_kDahpAJQ

data.title: function object(functor) and lambda expressions(anonymous functions) in GDscript
data.body:
Do you see these modules:

https://github.com/dbsGen/my_gdscript

---

example codes from repos:

```
func _ready():

    # Easier connection
    self.connect("renamed", on_renamed)

    var hello = "hello"
    # lambda expressions
    var lambda_func = func():
        print(hello)

    # or 
    func lambda_func2():
        print(hello)

    # lambda_func is a function object
    lambda_func.apply()
    lambda_func2.apply()

    # A native function object
    var native_func = self.set_name
    native_func.apply("new_name")


func on_renamed():
  print(get_name())
```

---

lambda functions Pros:

> Only one place function
> Code modularization
> Self-contained
> Reduce repitition
> Increasing the expressive power of the language
> Easy and optimized implementation of behaviour tree(see crytek softcode)
> Parallelization(with adoption in game scripting)

and Cons:

> Confusing(eventually)
> Functional thinking for starters and learning curve

---

---

and while loop improvements for glsl:
https://github.com/sheepandshepherd/godot-glsl-while

data.title: Added tooltip for a few buttons in sample library editor
data.body: I have added appropriate tool-tips on a few buttons that did not have any tool tips or descriptive text associated with them.

data.title: Added a few notes to classes.xml
data.body: I added a few tidbits of documentation regarding matrix32, array, and color, and sprite classes.

data.title: Add all collision shapes to a tile when converting scenes to TileSets
data.body:
Currently when converting a scene to a `TileSet`, only the first shape of each `StaticBody2D` is added to the tile.
For multiple shapes, one has to add multiple `StaticBody2D` nodes and give one shape to each.
For concave `CollisionPolygon2D` nodes in `BUILD_SOLIDS` mode, which split the concave polygon shape into multiple convex polygon shapes, only the first shape is added to the tile, making it impossible to use `CollisionPolygon2D` for concave polygons.

This change has all shapes added to the tile when converting.

Fixes #2331

data.title: SampleLibrary page prevents tab navigation
data.body:
#_(Not an important issue, but should be mentioned regardless)_

**How to replicate the problem:**
1. Start New Project (_optional_)
2. Create Node type "SamplePlayer".
3. In the Inspector, under "Config"->"Samples", change from _<null>_ to _New SampleLibrary_.
4. Click it again and select "Edit".

This will overlap your current page with the sample library page.
You are unable to leave this page by clicking on the tabs; 2D, 3D, Script or Help - so you are forced to finish whatever you are doing. A way I have found to leave this page (when not doing anything) it is by clicking on any node in the Scene window. 

Worth mentioning there is no indication of where you are (not counting inside the Inspector window). No title saying "Sample Library" or some other information to tell the user what "page" is he on. (Granted; most people usually know where they are and how they got there, but let us pretend the user is a dummy and create a user friendly program!)  :)

A suggestion to remedy this might be to make it _appear in a new window_ instead of replacing whatever page/tab you are currently in.
